poem:
**At the Cathedral**

On a day of solemn whispers,  
four presidents gather in coats of black,  
while outside, a familiar orange specter  
turns every glance into a flashbulb.  
History bends, unnoticed,  
as a nation contemplates the quiet room,  
where words and shadows linger longer  
than the fleeting noise of a departing motorcade.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Jimmy Carter’s death comes at a time when rancour and uncertainty prevail Early in Mike Bartlett’s 2022 stage play, The 47th, the funeral of former US president Jimmy Carter is held at Washington National Cathedral. Joe Biden, Barack Obama, George W Bush and Bill Clinton are all in attendance. Donald Trump is not invited but turns up anyway – and late. “He’s here to pay his disrespects, and use / A funeral for self-promotion,” Kamala". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
